conclusion: To determine how the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will change when the light source moves to the back right, we can analyze the relative positions and orientations of the objects.
Object A is a cylindrical object with a cross (a tape roll or medical bandage). Its shadow is cast to the left.
Object B is a small round cake or pastry. Its shadow is cast to the left.
Object C is a metallic, elongated object (possibly a nail). Its shadow is cast to the left.
Object D is a circular object (a ring). Its shadow is cast to the left.
The light source moves to the back right. This means the light rays now come from the back right to the front left.

premise: The light source moves to the back right, causing light rays to come from the back right to the front left.
conclusion: Since the light source is now coming from the back right, the shadows should shift to the front left relative to each object.

premise: Shadows shift to the front left relative to each object due to the light source moving to the back right.
conclusion: Shadow of Object A will move to the front left of the cylindrical object.

The size of the shadows may also change depending on the angle of the light. If the light is at a lower angle due to the change in position, the shadows could become elongated.

conclusion: As the angle decreases, the tangent value also decreases. However, since the height of the object above the ground remains constant, the horizontal displacement of the shadows increases, making the shadows longer.
